3.  Offsite Consequence Analysis.
The RMP Rule requires that offsite consequence analysis (OCA) be performed to estimate the potential for an accidental release of a regulated substance to affect the public or the environment.  This OCA includes the development of worst and alternative release scenarios for the release of flammable substances.  The OCA allows for the consideration of administrative controls in estimating potential scenario impacts.  

Worst Case Release Scenario
The worst case scenario, as based upon EPA-required assumptions, is highly unlikely, and has never occurred at this facility.

The worst case scenario associated with the release of a flammable substance is a vapor cloud explosion (VCE), involving the full inventory of the largest storage tank containing propylene.  The analysis assumes that the maximum possible inventory of 92,500 pounds is released, completely vaporizes and ignites, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The VCE would reach offsite and may affect nearby public receptors.

Alternative Case Release Scenarios  
The alternative case scenario for a flammable substance is a pipe failure from the first reactor, resulting in the release of 9,500 pounds of propylene.  This alternative case scenario does not have the potential to affect offsite receptors.  Emergency shutdown systems, fixed fire monitors, gas detectors, process interlocks, trained emergency response site personnel, and a process flare used for evacuating vessels are all a

vailable to actively mitigate this type of scenario.

Note:  The method used to estimate the residential population within distance to endpoint for both the Worst Case Release and Alternative Case Release Scenarios was LandView III software supplied by the USEPA et al.  Huntsman Marysville believes that the software highly overstates the residential populations for both scenarios, given that there is only one residence near the facility.  In fact, the alternative case release scenario does not reach beyond Huntsman Marysville's property boundary.  The LandView III population estimates were included in the plan data because of the software's wide use in preparing Risk Management Plans.

4. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps. 
Following is a brief summary of the elements that Huntsman's Marysville Site has implemented to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements outlined by EPA as well as with the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) process safety management (PSM) standard.  

7 Process Safety Information
 Huntsman's Marysville Site maintains a compilation of current and accurate written safety information to identify and understand the hazards of the process.  This includes information pertaining to:

7 Hazards of regulated substances:  For each regulated substance, there is a Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) which discusses the physical properties of the chemicals, exposure hazards, the required personal protective equipment and the appropriate first aid and emergency treatment for exposure.

7 The technology of the process:  Includes a discussion of process chemistry, safe upper and lower limits of temperature and pressure and analysis of consequences of deviation.

7 Equipment in the process:  Includes such information as materials of construction, diagrams of the piping and instrumentation, safety systems and design codes.

To perform the investigation, Huntsman Marysville has available an incident investigation team consisting of persons with the appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident.  A report is prepared at the conclusion of the incident investigation that addresses the incident, the factors that contributed to it, and recommendations resulting from the incident investigation.  Huntsman Marysville has established a system to promptly address and resolve the incident report findings and recommendations and to document their resolution.  Finally, incident reports are reviewed with all affected personnel.
 
7 Employee Participation
 Huntsman Marysville has developed a written action plan for employee participation in all aspects of its process safety management program.  Huntsman Marysville consults with employees on the conduct and development of PHA's and on the development of other elements of the process safety management program.  Huntsman Marysville ensures that all employees have access to PHA's and all other process safety management information.
 
7 Hot Work Permit
 Huntsman Marysville employs a hot work permit program for hot work operations conducted on or near the covered process (hot work generally involves electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing or similar spark-producing operations).  If any hot work is performed near the covered process, Huntsman Marysville issues a permit that documents the fire prevention and protection requirements for the operation, the date authorized for hot work, and the object on which the work is performed.  Hot work permits are kept on file until the work is complete.  
 
7 Contractors
 Huntsman Marysville has developed procedures for selecting and maintaining competent and knowledgeable contractors to ensure that they can safely perform their work.  Huntsman Marysville provides information to them about the hazards that may be present in the work area

HUNTSMAN MARYSVILLE - EXECUTIVE  SUMMARY
 
1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.  
Huntsman Marysville is committed to providing a safe, healthy and environmentally conscious work place for its employees and neighbors.  This is exemplified by the Marysville Site's 10-1/2 year 0 accidental release history.   The Huntsman Marysville site maintains a working PSM program, which implements a series of steps to prevent potential hazards associated with the process and assures a well-trained work force.   The PSM program further implements its policies with onsite procedures and manuals.  Huntsman Marysville participates with community agencies to develop emergency response plans and participates in cooperative training with these agencies.  Since our first production of quality polypropylene resin for the automotive and other industries in October 1988 to our June 1996 certification to the International Standards Organization (ISO) 9002 quality management process and a September 1998 Automotive Industry's QS-9000 quality management system certification, the Marysville Site has been a quality producer and a Responsible Care Neighbor for over 10 years in Eastern Michigan.

Huntsman's Marysville site is located in the southwestern corner of the City of Marysville, Michigan.  The site includes 58.6 acres, of which 20 acres have been developed.  The Marysville Site utilizes a continuous polymerization operation to convert pipeline-supplied propylene and ethylene into polypropylene pellets which molding companies then process into useful applications such as:  automotive trim, toys, medical containers, appliance parts, and other consumer products.  Propane is produced as a by-product of propylene purification.

2.  Regulated Substances.
Huntsman's Marysville Site has 2 regulated substances at the facility.  The two flammable substances are:

7 Propylene - Used to produce synthetic polymer resins.
  Propane - Used widely for home heating.

Note:  H

te has performed process hazard analysis (PHA) on the process to identify the potential hazards, the adequacy of the engineering and administrative controls and the ways to minimize those hazards.  The Marysville Site utilizes Fault Tree and HAZOP methodologies, both recognized and generally accepted methods, for identifying and evaluating hazards in the process.  The Marysville Site assigns employees to the PHA team who are knowledgeable in the PHA methodology and the specific process.  The PHA team develops recommendations to reduce the potential hazards which, if approved, are implemented within a reasonable period of time.
 
7 Operating Procedures
 Huntsman Marysville maintains written operating procedures that were developed in consultation with operators to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities associated with a covered process.  The procedures address steps for all operating phases, safety systems, control measures, and precautions to prevent exposures to process hazards.  The procedures are reviewed and revised periodically to ensure their accuracy and completeness.
 
7 Training
 Huntsman Marysville provides initial training as well as refresher training to employees to assure that the required level of skills and knowledge are maintained.  The training emphasizes safety and health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices.  All operators receive periodic refresher training.
 
7 Mechanical Integrity
 Huntsman Marysville has developed written procedures for maintaining the operating components of the process (including pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown system controls, and pumps) through the mechanical integrity program.  The program is comprised of well-trained personnel who follow maintenance, testing and inspection procedures that ensure proper function of process equipment.
 
7 Management of Change
 Huntsman Marysville has established and implemented written proc

edures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and any changes to the facility that affect a covered process.  The procedures assure that, prior to any change, the following issues are considered:  the technical basis for the proposed change; its impact on safety and health; associated modifications required of operating procedures; the necessary time period for the change; and any authorization requirements.  Employees involved in operating a process, as well as maintenance and contract employees whose job will be affected, are informed of and trained in the change.  If necessary, the process safety information and operating procedures are updated.  
 
 
7 Pre-Startup Review
 Huntsman Marysville performs pre-startup safety reviews when the addition of or a modification to the facility is made that is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.  The pre-startup safety review confirms, prior to the introduction of highly hazardous chemicals, that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; management-of-change requirements are met; and training of employees affected by modifications is complete.
 
7 Compliance Audit
 Huntsman Marysville performs audits of its compliance with the provisions of its process safety management program.  Teams comprised of employees, with appropriate knowledge of audit techniques, process safety and operating experience, conduct audits every three years to verify that the procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed.  The findings of the audit team are reviewed and appropriate corrective actions are implemented and tracked until resolved.
  
7 Incident Investigation
 Huntsman Marysville investigates any incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of covered chemicals.  The investigation is promptly conducted, comm

and has developed appropriate safe work practices.  Huntsman Marysville also evaluates the safety performance and programs of the contractors as a part of their continued employment.
 
5.    5 Year Accident History
 Huntsman Marysville has no accidental releases to report for the 5-Year Accident History that resulted in on-site deaths, injuries or significant property damage or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuation, shelter in place, property damage or environmental damage.
 
6.   Emergency Response Program.  Huntsman Marysville has a written emergency response program that contains procedures to be followed in the case of an accidental release.  These procedures include steps for informing local emergency response agencies and the public, and ensuring the correct use of emergency equipment with properly trained emergency response personnel.  In addition, Huntsman Marysville provides training to its emergency response employees who perform emergency response duties and to local emergency responders who may be called on to assist in emergency response.  Huntsman Marysville actively coordinates emergency response activities with local officials and groups.  Huntsman Marysville participates with the Marysville City Fire Department and the Saint Clair County Local Emergency Response Commission to develop emergency response procedures that identify resources, chemicals, contacts, and material safety data sheets for participating companies.  Other community activities include cooperative training between the Marysville Site and Saint Clair County Emergency Responders as well as making available equipment, technical information, and supplies for county responses.  The emergency response plan and its procedures are reviewed annually and updated as necessary.  Likewise, the emergency response equipment is maintained, tested and inspected periodically.
 
7. Planned changes to improve safety.  
Huntsman Marysville has an on-going commitment to improve safety and protect

the environment.  In addition to frequently scheduled internal company audits and inspections, Huntsman Marysville conducts an annual self-evaluation as part of the Chemical Manufacturers' Association (CMA) Responsible Care process safety code. The following health, safety and environmental improvements are anticipated during the next five years:

7 Installation of a new Distributed Computer Control System for improved and more efficient control of the polypropylene manufacturing process. 

7 Installation of additional Monomer Recovery equipment to capture process air emissions and recycle them back into the polypropylene manufacturing process.
